content:
I'm with you on this. It has driven me potty for a while. I've created a new bug for the latest beta to see if I can get more attention on this issue. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1849878

re : to get to this point (with no log-in)

You can read anything without a login. That includes using the Help Articles as well as any previously asked question.

You cannot create/ask a question without a login. You cannot comment - offer a helpful piece of information - without a login.

Any comment in a question will be emailed to whomever created the comment. So account is necessary. An account also sets up other private messaging system. It is also used to monitor inappropriate activity. An account also gets you access to a load of other Mozilla stuff eg: Firefox forum.

You can remain logged on if that suits you. You can easily locate your profile and hence any question you have asked or made a comment. Bookmark this : https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/user/druw/

Actually, I believe you have previously had some info about that already.

How to get to the point where you ask a question: Via Thunderbird

  1. Help > Thunderbird Help to auto opens in browser.
  2. scroll down and click on 'Ask the Community'
  3. search various topics or click on 'Ask Now'

If already in this forum searching/reading stuff: Top of webpage use the menu:

  1. Hover over 'Get Help' and select 'ASk a Question'
  2. Note this method is using all of Mozilla website, so you now need to choose what Subject/Topic - click on 'Thunderbird'
  3. search various topics or click on 'Ask Now'

You could also just do like many people do - create bookmarks:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/new/thunderbird
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
In Thunderbird Passwords are stored here:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • click on 'show Passwords'

If you need to update a password - right click on line and select 'Edit Password' clear contents and retype correct password. Do this for both mailbox:// or imap://...lines and also smtp://... line

Please note - Thunderbird just stores appropriate passwords so you do not need to enter it everytime a connection is made. All passwords can only be modified or reset via your webmail account.

Your password is the one you use to logon to webmail account. If you cannot remember password nor find it in Thunderbird then try to logon to webmail account via a browser and you will find they offer a 'Forgotten Password' link which you have to use to regain access to your account where you can reset pasword.

Some servers are now requiring the use of app specific passwords which you create and use instead of normal password.

If using Authentication 'Oauth2' then you will only be prompted for password - that is your normal password, if a new Oauth token needs to be created. You do not use 2 step authentication and app specific password if using Oauth Authentication.

creator: plwt

content:
You are talking about emails that are more than 10 years old. 'Q: When was the last time you actually opened to read any of those pre 2012 emails ?

If you can see headers but no contents then it means there is some data in the index file, but it cannot locate the email in the mbox file that stores the emails.

Possible reasons for problem: 1. If you originally moved emails from an imap account into Local Folders then you would have needed to ensure you had downloaded full copies before the move, otherwise you have only copied headers. Hence why I asked when you last accessed and read those old pre 2012 emails. Maybe they have not ever been accessed. Maybe they were never properly copied over to Local Folders.

2. You allow an Anti-Virus to scan your profile folders and it did not like the mbox file - maybe it found one email it did not like and decided to kill the whole file. That would mean the index file is still intact but cannot point to emails that do not exist. Strongly suggest you do not allow scanning of profile folders because AV's cause havoc.

3. Emails do exist, but the index file has become out of synch. This is an easy fix. Right click on folder and select 'Properties', click on 'Repair Folder' and click on 'OK'


Q: Do you have those emails in mbox files in the profile or not? 'Q: Do you have a backup of the Thunderbird profile folder?

How to check what is in 'Local Folders' foldre in profile:

  • Help > More TRoubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - Profile folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Click on 'Mail' folder to see contents
  • Click on 'Local Folders' folder to see contents.

I do not know the exact method of storage you have used. Here's an example If you have the pre 2012 emails in 'Archives' > '2011' folder. Click on 'Archives.sbd' folder to see contents Does the mbox file called '2011' (no extension) have a reasonable size? Does the 2011 mbox file exist ? Do you only see an index file eg: 2011.msf? If you see mbox file called '2011' (no extension) - Open mbox file called 2011 using Notepad (if size is less than 500MB) to see if it has emails. OR use Notepad++ if size is less than 2GB. If you only see '2011.msf' index file then you only have the index file and no emails.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The understanding of IMAP is that emails reside on the server and imap accounts on various devices hook up to server to see what is on server. IMAP accounts are usually offered a lot more space quota, but in your case IMAP may not necessarilly be a solution.

Thunderbird works best when you use the default location for storing emails.

Try: Create a folder in Dropbox called 'TBIRD' copy the profile name folder and put it in 'TBIRD'. so you have something like this. C:\Users\NAME\Dropbox\TBIRD\xxxxxxxx.default

where xxxxxxxx.default is the copied profile folder name. Remember you have to Exit Thunderbird first before you copy the profile name folder.

Then you need to set up a new profile which points to the new dropbox location. In Thunderbird

  • Help > TRoubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' near bottom - Profiles - click on 'about:profiles'

It opens in a new window

  • click on 'Create a new profile'
  • click on 'Next'
  • Give it a suitable name like 'DBOX profile'
  • click on 'Choose folder'
  • browse to where you have copied the profile

eg: C:\Users\NAME\Dropbox\TBIRD\xxxxxxxx.default

  • select profile name folder and click on 'Select folder'
  • Click on 'Finish'

This updates the 'profile.ini' file, so that a new profile location is added to list of profiles. So Thunderbird knows a profile exists in a different location - dropbox.

then you can choose which one you want to use as default. Maybe you keep using the original because it still exists in old location - remember I did say 'copy' profile name folder. Then you can perform a copy of profile and simply overwrite/update the one in dropbox. I suppose doing it that way means you effectively have two copies which may be useful. Or you can set the DBOX profile as default. Then other computer can access dropbox - create a new profile and point it to profile on dropbox.

A completely different approach is to keep a copy of the profile on a USB drive and just take it with you. Update profile on other laptop/computer and then use it. Perform backup to USB when finished and then update when you return. If you have a lot of emails this may not be so easy, but you could use an external hardrive.

OR use a USB/external hardrive with profile and use a portable version of Thunderbird - sorry do not know a lot about portableapps but this is a link to website:

  • https://portableapps.com/apps/internet/thunderbird_portable
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thanks for your replies... And yes, Paul, this is a duplicate because I wasn't sure if the one I sent to the Firefox community also went to Thunderbird community; obviously it does. Maybe my need has to do with the perhaps unusual way I use T'Bird. I get about 80 emails each day. Two or three times a day, using my browser, I always first check the Inbox on the server where my emails arrive (Earthlink in my case, although I also use gmail and some others). There I scan them all, and then read and delete many, having no further use for those partiicular ones. If time permits, I also look at what my filter on the server has put in Suspect Email, as there's just about always something of interest there. My server holds a limit of 100 MB (Inbox plus Suspect), and that limit is reached in a couple of days if I let it go. Then I leave the browser, fire up TB application on my computer, and download into my TB Inbox what I allowed to remain on my server's Inbox (not Suspect Emails; those will be deleted automatically in due course), deleting them from the server Inbox in the process. The wonderful TB filter sorts all incoming emails into a broad and deep set of folders that are my permanent store. This is where I keep media-emails for later reading, and most importantly where I go over the emails I need t spend more time with and reply to. Yes, these are stored (by TB) on my computer, just like the data files of any other application. But I have a Dropbox account and my other applications, such as WORD store copies of everything on Dropbox. That way, if I'm away from my main computer, I can still look at and work on those files. But I can't do that with Thunderbird. OR CAN I? THAT'S MY QUESTION!' I have two laptops, one of which is the "main computer" where I use TB and keep my TB Inbox. That computer has to go in for repair, which could take several days. So, I'm needing to use TB on a different computer during that time, and I don't want the server Inbox to fill up. Just looking at emails on the Server is not good enough. I can even reply to emails there, but those replies will not be associated correctly with the threads when eventually downloaded in TB on my main computer. I hope this gives a clear picture of my problem. I can take it up with Dropbox, but I thought I'd ask TB folks first. 

   Thanks for any further suggestions.

==John

(Edited to remove paragraph spaces to make question readable.)
creator: jlburch

content:
Hi

If your emails are of a POP type, where they download to the device - it is possible to move to IMAP, where your emails are held in the cloud and accessible from Thunderbird on different devices.

I made this change myself earlier this year. Lots of emails to move, it did take some time, but this guide was really useful:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/switch-pop-imap-account
creator: plwt

content: Thunderbird if correctly settings can be set where online inbox doesn't get deleted or removed when downloading to Thunderbird. Remember TB is only a email down-loader reader the actual email resides on the Online Email server until expires or user deletes the email. Thunderbird is not a cloud but local running software that connect to the Online email server. So not sure why you want to save to cloud when the Online email server saves it to cloud already.

content:
Hai alcuni problemi sul server con la configurazione del DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) e del Sender Policy Framework (SPF) per cui Google/Gmail blocca i tuoi messaggi. L'errore non è legato a Thunderbird ma al modo in cui lavora il tuo server di posta.

In problema lo devi quindi segnalare a chi ti fornisce la casella email ed eventualmente anche a Google/Gmail.

content: I think I fixed it! I missed a step in the process. I had to point the account to a different drafts folder, close Thunderbird, open Thunderbird and then it works. I was also able to point it back at the original drafts folder, close and reopen Thunderbird and then everything seems to be back to normal for now! So the step I missed was shutting down the app after changing the setting and then after launching the app again the change has worked.
